VNC and VPN clients and it works fine.

Question: Hi Prof, As hi lighted in red if joint is not implemented via product,  r joins s has been noted as below? Thank You Erik https://webcms3.cse.unsw.edu.au//static/uploads/pic/z5147351/f2e6ee5b91c40597a31956e6a0fd0a241f88d5531fed78e89016af05ea4bef10/Screen_Shot_2017-10-06_at_4.06.59_pm.png Thank you Rachid, my question was , since the join is expressed in the RA of product, I just wondering what is the actual implementation of join , does it get the product of the two relationship first and then Sel those with that match the condition? I know the result is much less than product, which could be the result of the later select after the product. All I want to know is the actually implementation of join get the product first?(as you indicated above is not?) in that case the RA product expression is just a representation of join but have nothing to do with the actual implementation? Thankyou Erik
reply: I did not get your question. This slide says that (Natural) Join can be expressed using other RA operators (Cartesian Product, Selection, and Projection).  Furthermore, since in general the number of tuples of a Join operation is much less than the number of tuples of a Product operation, Join is then not implemented using Product since the performance would be degraded. Please have a look at the following journal paper related to the topic: Mishra, P., & Eich, M. H. (1992). Join processing in relational databases. ACM Computing Surveys (CSUR), 24(1), 63-113. You can either get it through UNSW library or by using the following link: http://www.diku.dk/hjemmesider/ansatte/henglein/pa...

Question: Another question... definition of devision 1.r / s = r Div s = { t | t ∈ r[R-S] ∧ satisfy } 2.where satisfy = ∀ ts ∈ S ( &exists; tr ∈ R ( tr [S] = ts ∧ tr [R-S] = t ) ) since we are performing the attributes difference opeartion: t ∈ r[R-S] do we have to make sure that the common attributes have the same name in this case column B? if not should we rename the attribute to make them the same like join? Also, do we need to understand the logic representation? since the line 1. says there should be such tuple t that satisfy t ∈ r[R-S] and satisfy and then in line 2. when we define the condition satisfy there is a condition  tr [R-S] = t where we refer back to t is that recursive? we use a to be defined tuple as condition to define this to be defined tuple? Thank you Erik https://webcms3.cse.unsw.edu.au//static/uploads/pic/z5147351/280ae02ed44a6c04cf8944a41f4bf5601c985c7787022a06688f1fe390c49c83/Screen_Shot_2017-10-06_at_4.26.57_pm.png Okay, Thank you Prof!
reply: Yes you need to make sure that the common attributes have the same name in R and S relations (see Beers database example in next slides 37 and 38). There is no recursivity in the definition.  For readability reasons we wrote "satisfy" in another line.  We could have written the whole condition as follows: r / s = r Div s = { t | t ∈ r[R-S] ∧ (∀ ts ∈ S ( ∃ tr ∈ R ( tr [S] = ts ∧ tr [R-S] = t ) ) )  } Try to understand the explanation given in plain English: (1) consider each subset of tuples in R that match on t[R-S] (meaning consider only the attributes of R-S), (2) for this subset of tuples, take the t[S] (meaning consider only the attributes of S) values from each, and (3) if this covers all tuples in S, then include t[R-S] in the result. Division operation is used to handle queries that include "for all".

Question: Determine keys, in the following exercise how you get C? 4. FD = { ABH->C, A->D, C->E, F->A, E->F, BGH->E } BGH+ = ABCDEFGH => BGH is a key I understand BGH -> E, E -> F, F -> A, A -> D, that leave you ABDEFGH, how you determining C? is it, you decomposing ABH from ABDEFGH and you know ABH -> C, you got the C? Thanks, P.S. exercise taken from https://www.cse.unsw.edu.au/~cs9311/17s2/lectures/09/exercises/keys
reply: Yes. From ABDEFGH, since ABH -> C then BGH+ = ABCDEFGH.

Question: Dear Dr. Rachid Hamadi, (For the slide 'Normal Forms (cont)') This is the reference that I read: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Second_normal_form It says non-prime attribute instead of non-key attribute, and the definition of non-prime attribute is an attribute that is not a part of any candidate key of the relation. I also read the original paper , but it just introduces a simple case which has only one candidate key, which is a primary key as well, in the table. However, the wikipedia document above gives us the example when it violates the rule of 2NF for a non-primary candidate key. (I cannot use Wiki as a reference, but the example makes sense.) Best Regards, Curt Thanks very much for your answer.
reply: Thanks Curt for this important post. As I told you after the lecture, there are two definitions for 2NF and 3NF. The first one is based on primary keys as first proposed by Codd in 1972.  This is useful where primary keys have already been defined.  This definition does not take other candidate keys of a relation, if any, into account.  Section 15.3 (Normal Forms Based on Primary Keys) of Elmasri and Navathe textbook (Fundamentals of Database Systems, Elmasri and Navathe, 6th edition, 2011, Addison-Wesley) discusses that.  Please do read it. The second definition is more general in the sense that it takes ALL candidate keys of a relation, if any, into account.  Section 15.4 (General Definitions of Second and Third Normal Forms) of Elmasri and Navathe textbook (Fundamentals of Database Systems, Elmasri and Navathe, 6th edition, 2011, Addison-Wesley) discusses that.  Please do read it as well. Please note that the above do not apply to the definition of 1NF since it is independant of keys and functional dependencies.

Question: Hi Prof, What exactly is the difference between CREATE TYPE and CREATE DOMAIN, looks like they are doing the similar thing to define data type .... not sure if  CREATE TYPE is the similar spirit in C such as: typedef int number; number foo; There is not much mentioning the difference in the lecture. Thank you! Erik Thank you Prof ! I see ,so CREATE DOMAIN is a constrain instance of an existing data type whereas CREATE TYPE will define new data type.
reply: CREATE TYPE is used to define a new data type whereas CREATE DOMAIN is used to define a new domain of an existing type. Slide 8 mentions the difference between the two.  It says a domain (created using CREATE DOMAIN) is a constrained version of an existing type and CREATE TYPE is used to create either a tuple type or an enumerated type (that is, specifying elements and ordering) from scratch.

Question: Is there any difference in performance when we use "SELECT * FROM tbl1, tbl2 WHERE tbl1.id = tbl2.id" and "SELECT * FROM tbl1 JOIN tbl2 ON tbl1.id = tbl2.id" ?
reply: No, there is no difference.

Question: Hi John, for the second relationship that you have mentioned that because the course to staff is a full relationship so that the convenor(staff) should not be null.... however , from the diagram does it says that all course must have at most one staff, which means that a course could have 0 convenor from staff, so the convenor does not have to be null?? thank you! Erik https://webcms3.cse.unsw.edu.au//static/uploads/pic/z5147351/65ddcce353dfce3f0eb3fcf6d26f731e0710bfcff67f48e166d48caf5a8c51ac/Screen_Shot_2017-08-08_at_9.15.57_pm.png Thank you Rachid! it is now clear :)
reply: The relationship means a course is thought by at most one staff and a staff teaches several courses.  However, since the participation is total from the course side this means ALL courses should appear in this relationship.  Hence, each course must have one staff meaning convenor should be "not null".  On the other hand, we may have a staff who does not teach any course because of the partial participation.  Hope this is clear.

Question: Hello Rashid, Do you recommend any good ER designer tool suitable to this particular dialect of ERD? Thank you. This was what I was planning to use, but it's missing overlap/disjoint gates, and both carnality and participation are denoted differently too. Is it ok to use it for our purposes? This sounds easy enough, thank you.
reply: https://erdplus.com/#/standalone ) is the closest ERD tool, to the notation we are using in class, I could find.  You can save as a .erdplus or export as a PNG file. I do prefer that you stick to the notation that we are using in this class.  However, if you know how to translate the cardinality and participation used in our class notation to the ones used by this tool then it should be fine.  Another way to generate something similar to our class notation is to use this convenient tool to draw the ER diagram without cardinality and participation then export it as a png file.  Finally, edit the png file with a graphical software and add the "one" cardinalities (that is, the missing arrows) and the "total" participations (making them thick).

Question: Hello Dr Hamadi, Thank you for your lecture. I was not quite clear about slides #41 and 42. What is the difference between a total relationship and one-to-one cardinality? Do they represent the same thing? Thank you. Feng Thank you sir. This is perfectly clear.
reply: Actually, I did not go through the last slides (from slide 40) in our first lecture since class time was over. I will start my week 2 lecture by going through the rest of slides not covered in week 1 lecture. Total (relationship) participation and one-to-one (relationship) cardinality are NOT the same. In slide #41, the cardinality between Customer and Loan entities is many-to-many meaning a Customer can have zero or more Loans and a Loan can be taken by zero or more Customers. Partial participation (indicated by a normal line) means not all Customers are participating in the relationship TakesOut. Total participation (indicated by a thick line or double line) means ALL Loans are participating in the relationship TakesOut. In other words, for Total participation, every Loan must have a Customer associated to it via TakesOut relationship. One-to-one cardinality in slide #42 (between Manager and Branch entities) means a Manager manages at most one Branch and a Branch is managed by at most one Manager. Why I am using "at most" since both participations are partial. If, for instance, between "Manages" and "Branch" the directed line was thick (or double) then the meaning will be "a Branch is managed by exactly ONE Manager". Hope this is clear. Anyway, I will be discussing it in our next lecture as I said.

Question: Hi Professor, As we know BCNF may produce redundancy, and if we choose different order the result may be different. Here is an example R = SBD fds = { SB --> D, D -->B } If I deal with D à B firstly, obviously D à B satisfies BCNF. Then R1 = SD, fds1 = {S à D} Obviously Sà D satisfies BCNF So the result could be (D,B) (S,D) Another way R = SBD fds = { SB --> D, D -->B } SB à D satisfies D (SB is the candidate key) Then R1 = SB fds1 = {} (Trivially ) So SB satisfies BCNF So the result could be (SB,S) (S,B) Which is right? As I know strategy_1 ignore the composition of SB, strategy_2 produce the redundancy. Thank you !
reply: The way you write and explain is not fully correct, for instance, instead of "satisfy" you should say "violate". First the keys are SD (since SD+ = SDB) and SB (since SB+=SBD) If you start with D-->B, the result will be SD and DB If you start with SB-->D, this FD does not violate BCNF since SB is a key.  Meaning you will go and check the other FD which is D-->B which will take you to the above case, that is, SD and DB.

Question: Hi, is there a good reason why postgre does not automatically enforce that the data types of foreign key and the primary key it references match? For example, if one is text and the other is integer, postgre won't let you create the tables. But if one is varchar(1) and the other is text, it lets you do it (although if you try to insert values, you are effectively limited to varchar(1)). Thank you.
reply: Foreign key refers to another table's primary key and obviously both need to have the same datatype. However, PostgreSQL and other SQL implementations are not strict on that since they allow compatible types such as one being text and the other being varchar(1) as you mentioned.  However, SQL standard does specify that both datatypes must be the same. For instance, if datatype is string, they must have the same length.

Question: Dear professor : I have some questions in lab 9 1. how can I know the result of supplier supply  the same part from the code above. I can only get that these suppliers supply all jobs but not supply the same part to them . 2. I think that this code may return (SidA , sname ,status,scity ,SidB , sname ,status,scity ) not a tuple of (sida,sidb) https://webcms3.cse.unsw.edu.au/https://webcms3.cse.unsw.edu.au/static/uploads/pic/z5187969/6e942b2dd2e81a2e3cf836cd8f6673313b777d449a933e99f4bb830adc5cefc9/7U5WNXZJHWXJ2XKUH1G.png
reply: 1. Actually if you look at the answer carefully, (SPJTriples Div AllJobNums) gives a table with supplier and part attributes (see definition of Division operation).  Then, we do projection of the result on supplier (i.e., Proj[supplier](SPJTriples Div AllJobNums)) which give a result with supplier attribute only.  Review Division operation in slides 35-38. 2. No. It returns (sidA,sidB) tuples. AllPairs is a table of (sidA,sidB) pairs.  Then we apply a Selection operation on it (last line).  Since selection is reducing the number of rows and does not modify the number of columns (which is the role of Projection operation) there will be then no change in terms of the type of tuples to be output which is (sidA,sidB).  The note after the solution explains what the Selection operation does: "It takes pairs of supplier numbers (sidA,sidB), finds the set of parts supplied by each, and then checks that these sets are equal. The sidA<sidB term simply avoids having trivial pairs like (S1,S1) and also avoids having both (S1,S2) and (S2,S1)". Hi, I think you are right. Will check it and get back to you. Mohammad, these Lab 9 answers are correct.

Question: Hi professor, I have some question. Could you please help me solve thes questions? 1. What is the difference between INFORMATION_SCHEMA and other tables such as pg_tables? I have read the examples and I am quite confused about these because sometimes INFORMATION_SCHEMA is used in some programs but sometimes pg_tables is used in other programs. 2. Is it necessary for us to memory and master in these tables (that is, INFORMATION_SCHEMA and pg_tables, etc.) ? The examples in the slide in really complicated... 3. In the lecture (https://www.cse.unsw.edu.au/~cs9311/18s2/lectures/09/slide028.html), it mentioned the keys of R implied by F, but I cannot fully understand what this means. Could you please give me some examples of the keys of R implied by F？ Thanks very much!
reply: 1. The information_schema (see Chapter 36. The Information Schema ) is the SQL standard that consists of a set of views that contain information about the objects defined in the current database. The information schema is therefore portable unlike the system catalogs (see Chapter 51. System Catalogs ), which are specific to PostgreSQL. 2. You do not have to memorise all these names.  However, overall, you need to know what these catalogs are used for. 3. Slide 29 gives a lot of examples. For instance, assume R = ABCDEFG and F = {A --> B, C --> D, E --> FG} then ACE is a key of R implied by F (since ACE+ = ABCDEFG = R).

Question: Hi, is the result of BCNF decomposition unique? or the answer can be different? My answer for Q5 09s1 exam is: AB, AC, DE, DF, A. I am not sure whether it is correct or not? No it's not unique. Did you mistype your answer? I don't think you can get a single column for a table. The choice of FD that you choose that violates BCNF constraint will lead you to different answers. like that https://webcms3.cse.unsw.edu.au//static/uploads/pic/z5077894/6dc2d21b71d0736166ecf0c2ef6c6fcca169674f2237bf83ad92714563d981d2/image.jpg I think I got single "A" because of using the function dependency "D->F" which is what I calculated from "D->E" and "E->F". And then because A is the super key, so got it left. Can we do that? (For the calculation of function dependency) Let's assume the working is correct up to that point. Then for R111 = ADF, the split would be AD, DF. Since D->F violates BCNF. We need an attribute to reference the DF relation. So you will never have the case of a single attribute like that. A is a key so A is also a superkey. The functional dependency, A->B does not violate BCNF condition (1).  So the first split of ACDEF, AB is incorrect.
reply: Most of the decomposition algorithms are non-deterministic, which means that there are multiple correct solutions.

Question: Can we do this, the lectures seem to say its not possible to enforce total participation in a subclass relationship but I think this does, you have to use a transaction and will fail if the foreign keys in People are not set. Is this possible? If not why not? create table People( id int primary key check (id is betweem 10000 and 99999), name varchar(50) not null studentid int  unique staffid int  unique constraint totalpart check (staffid is not null or studentid is not null) ) create table Staff( id int references Person(id) on delete cascade, salary float check (salary >0) not null, primary key id ) create table Student( id int references Person(id) on delete cascade, degree varchar(20) not null, primary key id ) alter table People ( add constraint studentid_FK foreign key (studentid) references Student(id) deferrable initally deferred, add constraint staffid_FK foreign key (staffid) references Staff(id) deferrable initally deferred, ) "assuming you can get the tuples inserted, given the circular dependency" ^ is the circular dependency thing an issue for these sorts of tasks? you can use a transaction to avoid the circular dependency. thats why the foreign keys are marked as deferable... I got the idea from here https://dba.stackexchange.com/questions/35302/er-d...
reply: Your strategy seems to force every People tuple to also be either a Student or Staff or both, so looks like it solves the total participation problem (assuming you can get the tuples inserted, given the circular dependency). But, if the semantics are strictly disjoint subclasses, then it doesn't work ( totalpart allows overlapping subclasses). Presumably you could overcome this by tweaking the totalpart constraint. Typically requires different solutions for different DBMSs. However, solvable.

Question: How to deal with overlapping, partial using ER mapping? Is there any example we can refer to? This is the example shown in slide 14, but I don't really get how it deal with overlapping and partial? It just simply splits three subclasses into three separate tables. https://webcms3.cse.unsw.edu.au/https://webcms3.cse.unsw.edu.au/static/uploads/pic/z5093599/1f876b92410e8d9f3dbbdfe8be4a0780bdeabb25fc3a4599c9fd0bf1dde02cd7/Capture.png I feel like I just posted a comment that was possible to enforce total participation without using triggers. Can you tell me why its not possible?
reply: See Lecture 3 Slide 14 (there is a link for a solution at the bottom of this slide). Overlapping means a student can be, for instance, a masters and a research at the same time and this is possible in the above schema.  Remember in the the tables ugrad, masters, and research there is sid attribute which is a primary key and a foreign key that refers to student. Partial means not every student participates in ugrad, masters, and research tables which is the case. Thus, a record in student table does not necessary have to appear in any of the three sub-entities (ugrad, masters, and research). What you need to understand is that this ER mapping does not cater for other cases such as, for instance, disjoint and total (i.e., each student belongs to exactly one subclass).  To do so, we need triggers.

Question: Can we use 'limit' for sql in the exam? because I heard we can't use it in our ass1 Yeah, I want to use it with order by, like q3 in 12s1 exam, I need to find the most players, so I use order by to sort my result and use limit to get the first one I think that could cause issues if they changed the database so that there were 2 results with the most players instead of 1. so use 'max' is better right? I believe that won't return a tuple. You could do a subquery. E.g. select * from items where cost = (select max(cost) from items) EDIT: But if you just want the max value max should be fine I believe.
reply: limit is a hack and violates the relational idea behind relational databases. It also introduces a certain degree of non-determinism (i.e. the result set is dependent on the internally-determined order that tuples are delivered). If you insist on using it, it should always be used in conjunction with order by

Question: Can I ask why GE is not in the table this semester but appear in the next year? <u></u> https://webcms3.cse.unsw.edu.au/https://webcms3.cse.unsw.edu.au/static/uploads/pic/z5093599/27c40f2fd4afd02002b7f5be84cc10d106ef36dce17461fcc8f4880b54175bec/Capture.png Can we regard this MR rule as a default for every program? Since if we don't find the rule and read it we don't know it is related to second level at all. https://webcms3.cse.unsw.edu.au/https://webcms3.cse.unsw.edu.au/static/uploads/pic/z5093599/e7dd5b5c79c1f83987373e25d21b1303285bf8ba26b88d7bc8fee884b953f715/Capture.png There are a lot of rules with the name 'GE maturity', could we go by name?
reply: According to the rules, students can't take Gen Ed courses until they've completed 48UC, which wouldn't be the case until their second year of study (which presumably isn't 11s2) It's not directly related to second level anyway. The 48UC minimum is the real requirement ... that generally means second year, because you typically take 8 courses (i.e. 48 UC). If a student failed a course or two in first year, they wouldn't be eligible for GE until they'd taken some more courses in second year. It's not default. It needs to be in the rule set for the program before you apply it. No. Look for MR rules and then look for the academic object set they apply to. The names are arbitrary and inconsistent across programs.

The system went on and calculated q3 since q1raw (or quiz#1 mark out of 4) is already available.  Hence, every one who submitted quiz#1 had the same mark for quiz#3.  Unfortunately, for some of you, I fixed it now !!

Question: Can anyone help me with this please? I have tried doing it over and over, but its still not working. It looks like the pgsql didn't install properly and I need to remove it? https://webcms3.cse.unsw.edu.au//static/uploads/pic/z5130780/71d103f0f8c7a1ee774df5ff7fd4d3c67fda2410be11536eb5e0fe7545114f0e/Screen_Shot_2018-03-29_at_11.42.59_am.png This is what happened after I run the commands. and this is the script In /srvr/z5130378/env. https://webcms3.cse.unsw.edu.au//static/uploads/pic/z5130378/e838a9dd43095cc1023d78af05024f9d7ff8d370eaa28a43fdb638dbfe85a9fc/Screen_Shot_2018-03-29_at_2.20.17_PM.png Its working now! reply: Since I can't see your precise setup, this is hard to work out. First, did you run priv srvr? Next, what's in the file /srvr/z5130378/env? What do you see if you run the commands: echo $PATHecho $PGDATA ? That's an old setup (e.g. COMP3311 17s1). Your env file should look like YOU=$(/usr/bin/id -nu) PGHOME=/usr/lib/postgresql/9.4 export PGPORT=5432 export PGDATA=/srvr/$YOU/pgsql export PGHOST=$PGDATA export LD_LIBRARY_PATH=$PGHOME/lib export PATH=$PGHOME/bin:~cs3311/bin:$PATH Try changing the contents of your env file to this and see whether that fixes it. If not, go back to the "Setting up your PostgreSQL server" lab and set up your server again.

Others who also have similar concerns about quizzes please do let me know.

Question: Hi, by any chance we can be given access to the solutions of exercises in the given lecture slides? thx
reply: The solutions for the exercises we do in the lecture are available to students by clicking on the [Solution] link at the bottom of the slides where the exercises are given.  Please let me know which one(s) is(are) not available.

Question: Hi, regarding assignment 1, I'm finding Q1 a bit ambiguous; which grades would be counted as 'has studied' from the UNSW grades list: https://student.unsw.edu.au/grade The specs provide the following statement, although, in my mind having 'studied' a particular subject does not necessarily mean it was successfully completed. "note that the mark alone is not sufficient to determine whether a student has successfully completed a course; they need a passing grade to ensure this (the set of grades indicating a pass includes SY, PC, PS, CR, DN, HD ... there is also a PT grade which is no longer used but is included to allow us to deal with old data)" I have done a search including all the grades I would consider as having 'studied' a course, although get a few more results than that from the q1_expected table. Some clarification on the grades counted as 'studied' would be appreciated, Thank you
reply: Hello Simon, Q1 says "Define an SQL view Q1(unswid,name) that gives the student id and name of any student who has studied more than 65 courses at UNSW".  And you are right while saying: "'studied' a particular subject does not necessarily mean it was successfully completed". Then you went on and looked at the type of grades that determines a pass which is unnecessary. Actually "studied a course" in Q1 means simply "enrolled in the course" (irrespective of what mark and grade the student got) and there is a table in the database that records this information. Hope this is clear.

Question: Hi, For assignment 1, I know my SQL statement for Q1 produces the correct output, but when I enter "select check_q1();" it returns "no q1 view; did it load correctly?" I re-saved my updated a1.sql but still not working. How am I supposed to get it to load correctly?
reply: It looks like you did not load your a1.sql since the view Q1 is not known.  Remember you need to do something similar to the following steps to check that your solutions are correct: $ dropdb a1 ... remove any existing DB $ createdb a1 ... create an empty database $ psql a1 -f ..../mymyunsw.dump ... load the MyMyUNSW schema and data $ psql a1 -f ..../check.sql ... load the checking code $ psql a1 -f a1.sql ... load your solution You can do that incrementally after writing your answers to the questions one by one.

Question: Hi, I am doing assignment 1, but I always get error " psql: FATAL: sorry, too many clients already " when I run "psql a1". Can you increase the limit?
reply: No. Because you are the server administrator for your own PostgreSQL server, not us. This kind of question really needs someone to look at exactly what you're doing to have any chance of diagnosing the problem. For a start, are you working on your own machine or on a CSE machine? Are you on Grieg? Have you run "priv srvr"? Have you run your own PostgreSQL server? If all of that's true, then start looking, using the Linux "ps" command, at whether you've got any suspended "psql" processes hanging around. If you do, "fg" them and "\q" them to make them go away. If none of that works, come to a consultation session (Wed 10-11 in K17-410).

Question: Is assignment 1 meant to be visible yet? I can see it on upcoming due dates but get a permission error when clicking the link. I don't think it can be viewed yet. Even I'm getting the permission error
reply: Ellen and Varnika, Asignment 1 is not visible yet. It will be released sometime in Week 3.

Question: Hi I have question about the 3311 lab. I saw 9311 have lab but 3311 doesn't, so comp3311 doesn't have lab right? thanks!
reply: COMP3311 doesn't have lab classes. However, it has Prac Exercises which have the same function (getting you to practice using technologies), but which you do in your own time. We'll have consultations where you can get help on these exercises if you get stuck.

Question: Hi, Would like some clarification. Under assessment only quizzes, assignment 1 and 2, and exams are part of our final mark. Would you like use to submit anything for the "exercises" and "prac work" listed under "Course Work"? If yes, where? Thanks
reply: Hello Alvin, Theory Exercises and Prac Work are not submittable.  However, you are highly recommended to do them in your own time as a practice and revision for final exam (both written and practical).  And most importantly, you will not fully understand the concepts introduced in lecture classes without you going through and doing them. Thank you. Best regards, Rachid
